title: System fonts issue!
content:
Hello all,   
First I would like to introduce myself as the newest member in this forum or the rookie ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20050526222023im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)   
I am counting on the expertise of a lot of members here to find an answer to my problem.   
I am a graphic designer, just switched to a PC, I finally converted the postcript fonts and will be using ATM light to turn them on/off.   
This is where I get confused, I realized I have more than 300 fonts installed in WindowsXP, from what I understand it shouldn't be more that 200 or the system may run a little slow. I am thinking about converting most of them to type1 and manage them through ATM, But I don't know witch ones are system fonts, and have to be managed by windows.   
Please help.   
Thank you.
author: pixelmaster

comments.content:
I told you I was a rookie, I noticed I didn't spell a word the right way, wanting to fix it I ended up posting the thread twice.   
I am sorry!
The critical system fonts have a .fon extension. AFAIK, those are the ones that must be managed by Windows.

There are plenty of critical system fonts that are TrueType fonts (.ttf). I wouldn't touch Tahoma, for instance.   
   
Additionally, I don't know anybody who thinks it is sensible to convert Windows system fonts to Type 1. Why on earth would one do such a thing? You'd break the extended language support and the TrueType hinting. In any case, it is not permitted under the Windows license.   
   
I can't find the list of Windows system fonts, although I know it's on the MS web site.   
   
Regards,   
   
T

Steve, thanks for the hint, I noticed the .FON have a different looking icon.   
   
Thomas, I want to make sure I don't mess with the system fonts, and convert the rest to type1 so I can manage them with ATM light, and not have them slow down my system.   
   
Thank you guys for the feedback, please keep it coming.

ATM Light doesn't really "manage fonts" in the sense of turning them on and off and handling sets. For that you need ATM Deluxe (or one of its competitors). ATM Light just provides rasterization services, and most of that is now build into the OS (except for multiple master support).   
   
Changing the format of the font won't help system performance. For that you need to deactivate some fonts, which you can do just as easily regardless of font format.   
   
These days Windows can handle having hundreds or even thousands of active fonts. The main thing that gets slowed down is that certain applications enumerate all the fonts when the app is launched. Plus anything with a WYSIWYG font menu may have some extra work to do. But all this is pretty much linear; there's no magic number where things suddenly get much worse. 300 fonts isn't that much worse than 200.   
   
Regards,   
   
T

It seems that I neglected some parameters. let me restructure my question.   
I have two collections of fonts tha came with some clip arts. True Type, and Postcript, about 1000 fonts each.   
What/how would be the best way for me to use these fonts. (windowsXP) photoshop, illustrator, quark, dreamweaver...

If (cough, cough) there's any worth keeping, only install those. Then with ATM Deluxe or Suitcase you can turn them on and off individually.   
With dreamweaver, you won't be using fonts other than system fonts or default sans or serifs, unless there's something I don't know about. Nobody will be able to see anything else, unless they have the same font installed and active.   
Atm deluxe can handle both ttf & ps. Also, if you need type reunion, it comes bundled with atm deluxe.   
I'm not sure atm light handles ttf, and if it does, deluxe isn't so expensive anyways. And, like Thomas said, windows rasterizes most everything already.

A list of MS supplied fonts by version and application can be found here.   
   
 [http://www.microsoft.com/typography/fonts/default.aspx](http://web.archive.org/web/20050526222023/http:/www.microsoft.com/typography/fonts/default.aspx)   
   
Cheers   
Neil
